Testing LLMs in RAG is hard - is failure due to retrieval (top-k) or synthesis (LLM)? 

Make it easier: Sanity-check LLMs in isolation with *ground-truth* context.

The HotpotQA benchmark provides exactly that (‚Äúdistractor‚Äù setting), and it‚Äôs now available in @llama_index üëá https://t.co/E0N1lJnagc

1681816022557560832.text:
Using top-k lookup for retrieval in your RAG system is fast but imprecise ü§î

Using cross-encoding as a reranking step can dramatically speed up LLM inference time AND improve accuracy! ‚ö°Ô∏è

Here's how to implement it in @llama_index üëá: https://t.co/CCfEzs5LOH https://t.co/1sTfq9M0c2

1681816031134883840.text:
We can use cross-encoding as a *reranking step* AFTER  existing top-k lookup. This allows you to set a much larger top-k for retrieval when building an LLM QA system.

In @llama_index, if you set top_k=10, by default LLM will take ~30 seconds. https://t.co/Q18umZj6b6

1681816034553237504.text:
But with cross-encoding based reranking/pruning, the LLM synthesis takes 4 seconds, and the answer is better.

Giving LLM agents access to data is more complex than simply letting them use a GET endpoint. ‚ö†Ô∏è

If the endpoint returns too much data (e.g. an entire @wikipedia page), it will overflow the context window! 

Instead: ‚Äúcache‚Äù data and then search üí°. Available in @llama_index üëá https://t.co/EbybycYpW1

1679523830681976832.text:
The search tool, if called, will then call this index to query for the right result! 

Here is a concrete example of using load and search tools on top of an underlying Wikipedia endpoint.

The agent will first cache the Wiki page in an index, and then query it after üóÉÔ∏è https://t.co/7o1O2NF8vu

1679523832833671168.text:
The load and search tool spec, as well as our `OnDemandLoaderTool`, present different ways of storing/indexing data.

Take a look at our guide here: https://t.co/wl5Ic71fKI

Wikipedia tool: https://t.co/Nbq10yo5bN

1679523826319912961.text:
Solution: We have a `LoadAndSearchToolSpec` that can take in any existing Tool as input. 

It will then return two tools - a ‚Äúload‚Äù tool and ‚Äúsearch‚Äù tool. 

The load tool will call underlying tool and store in an index cache (powered by LlamaIndex)‚Ä¶
